ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Lots of knowledge and insight about inequality, economics and politics in modern Latin America

I learned about how different economic, social and political issues perpetuate inequality in Latin America and how these issues interact and accelerate each other. In doing so, we learned about the history of different Latin American countries, the main issues contributing to inequality , the political trajectory of the region, and different analytical methods.

This course was a great experience in interacting with the major research in Latin American political inequality. Engaging with the scholarship and the presentation/discussion format was very practical.

Studied Latin America as a region, looking at the ways in which inequality is observed, how it is measured, and theories about how it came to be. Topics included perceptions of inequality, corruption, violence, clientelism, and the trajectory of democracy in the region. Learned how to read academic papers and studies both on the quantitative and qualitative side.
I learned how to analyze research papers efficiently and effectively, and I gained insight into the politics and inequality in many latin american countries.

This course provides great insight and skills for thinking about Latin American politics and the issues that the region faces. It's really useful for understanding what's unique about inequality in Latin America and what makes it so different from an American context. Furthermore, there is a presentation assignment that really lets you delve deep into one country's politics plus learn about other countries through others' presentations.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths: very smart and thoughtful professor, interesting readings & content. Weaknesses: low student involvement throughout most of the course. The discussion questions she introduced in the last third were helpful--I will add another suggestion later in review.

Strengths: Diversity in readings both in perspectives and in type, well curated syllabus, and Professor de La O is great, guides class conversation very well

Weaknesses: You don't really go into any topic in depth so some weeks it felt like we did not learn much about that specific issues, also sometimes the class conversation seemed to be stuck / unproductive
The course could've been helped by more current events in the syllabus/readings to apply the research to current circumstances, instead of the bulk being in student led presentations.
Towards the end of the course Prof. De La O gave us open ended reading responses  I thought these were a great way to reflect on the material and prepare for class.
The course could become somewhat dry in structure as it was mainly reading research papers, but I enjoyed our discussions and the level of engagement in the class.

Strengths: interesting readings; great discussion and the seminar approach is very engaging; not too many assignments so you can focus on truly engaging with the readings; and professor De La O is very knowledgeable on the subjects and the countries.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, it's a very interesting course and I feel that I learned a lot about the region. As someone who had little personal background in the region before taking the course I didn't think this was a barrier to understanding/participation and it was great to hear a lot of perspectives I wouldn't otherwise be exposed to.
Yes, this is a must-take course for anyone interested in Latin America and Professor de La O is excellent. The workload is not stressful and the readings are generally interesting.
Any student interested in understanding the complexities of Latin American politics and socioeconomic dynamics should make this course a priority.
I would absolutely recommend this course to anyone who is interested in not just Latin America, but politics in general.
Yes, if at all interested in latin america or inequality.

I would definitely recommend this course as it was engaging and I feel as though I learned a lot but it also wasn't too stressful. I would definitely recommend taking perhaps a more introductory level course on Latin America beforehand as I feel like some general knowledge about the region will make the discussions and readings that much more engaging, but you can also definitely learn along the way.
